sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The &app; application is a simple calculator that performs a variety of functions. &app; has three modes:

listitem.para: Basic Mode provides the standard calculator functions. You can also store numbers in 10 different memory registers, and easily retrieve and replace the numbers in the memory registers. Basic Mode is the default mode. All of the Basic Mode functions are also available in each of the other modes.
Financial Mode provides several complex financial functions.
Scientific Mode provides many additional mathematical functions, including trigonometric and logical functions. You can also store your own functions and constants, when using Scientific Mode.

sect2.title: To Use Calculator Functions
sect2.para: To perform a calculation, use one of the following methods:

listitem.para: Click on the &app; buttons to enter numbers and functions.
Give focus to the &app; window, then use the keyboard or numeric keypad to specify the calculation that you want to perform.

sect2.para: The numbers that you enter, and the results of calculations, are displayed in the display area. You can enter numbers of up to forty digits.

To copy the result of a calculation, choose
Edit Copy . You can paste the value into another application.

To paste a previously copied value into the display area, choose
Edit Paste .

&app; automatically displays large numbers (>40 digits) and small numbers as exponential numbers. For example, 1.23e+37 signifies 1.23 multiplied by 10 to the power of 37. If you enter 0.00001 and the accuracy is set to less than 5 radix places, &app; displays the number as 1e-5, which signifies 1 multiplied by 10 to the power of -5. sect2.title: To Perform Basic Calculations
sect2.para:
Basic Mode is displayed by default when you first start &app;. To explicitly invoke Basic Mode, choose

sect3.title: To Set the Accuracy
sect3.para: To set the accuracy of the display area and of the memory registers, click on Acc, and select the appropriate accuracy level from the popup menu. Up to 9 significant digits (radix places) can be displayed. The default accuracy is 2 radix places.

The keyboard equivalent of Acc is A. If using the keyboard equivalent A, you can use the keyboard to specify the appropriate number of radix places. For example, A 4 specifies an accuracy of 4 numeric places.

sect3.title: To Use the Calculator Memory Registers
sect3.para:
You can store values in any of the ten &app; memory registers (R0 to R9). To display the memory registers, choose
View Memory Registers .
describes the memory functions that are available.

entry.para: Stores the current contents of the display area in the specified memory register. Click on Sto, and select the appropriate memory register from the popup menu. If using the keyboard equivalent S, you can use the keyboard to specify the appropriate memory register. For example, S 2 stores the current contents of the display area in memory register R2.

All memory registers are cleared when you exit &app;. To clear a memory register during a &app; session, click on Clr, then click on Sto, and select the appropriate memory register from the popup menu.
The value 22 is stored in memory register R2

Retrieves the contents of the specified memory register. Click on Rcl, and select the appropriate memory register from the popup menu. If using the keyboard equivalent R, you can use the keyboard to specify the appropriate memory register. For example, R 2 retrieves the current contents of memory register R2 into the display area.

Exchange Memory Register Value and Displayed Value

If using the keyboard equivalent X, you can use the keyboard to specify the appropriate memory register. For example, X 2 exchanges the current value of the display area with the contents of memory register R2.

sect3.title: To Display ASCII Values
sect3.para:
To display the ASCII value of a character, choose
Edit Insert ASCII Value .
The Insert ASCII Value dialog is displayed:

Enter the required character in the Character field, and click on Insert. The ASCII value of that character (in the appropriate numeric base) appears in the display area. For example, the ASCII value of B in decimal base is 66.

sect2.title: To Perform Scientific Calculations

To change to Scientific Mode, choose
View Scientific Mode .
When you change to Scientific Mode, the following Scientific Mode buttons are displayed above the Basic Mode buttons:

sect3.para: To set the numeric base, select one of the buttons described in .

sect3.title: To Set the Display Type
sect3.para: To set the display type, select one of the buttons described in .

entry.para: Sets the display type to Engineering format. Results are displayed in scientific notation; the exponent is always a multiple of three.
Sets the display type to Fixed-Point format. Results are not displayed in scientific notation. This is the default display type.
Sets the display type to Scientific format. Results are displayed in scientific notation, with a fixed number of numeric digits.

sect3.para: To perform logical calculations, use the buttons described in .

sect3.title: To Enter Exponential Numbers
sect3.para: To enter exponential numbers, use the Exp button. The keyboard equivalent is E.

The Exp button allows you to enter numbers in scientific notation; that is, mantissa * 10exponent. The current (non-zero) value in the display area is the mantissa; if the current value is zero, the mantissa is 1.0. The next number entered is the exponent.

When you click on Exp, the calculator displays . + to represent 10 to the power of the next number that you enter. For example, if you enter 5 Exp 2 = the calculator displays 500. Note that changing the sign of the number (using the +/- button) must be the last part of the operation.

sect3.title: To Use Constant Values
sect3.para: To show the available constants, click on Con. The keyboard equivalent is #. A popup menu displays the list of defined constant values; select a constant from the menu to enter its value in the display area. If using the keyboard equivalent #, you can use the keyboard to specify the constant. For example, # 3 enters the value of constant C3 (that is, 3.14) in the display area.
&app; provides ten default constant values, as described in the following table:

entry.para: kilometers per hour / miles per hour
Multiply the current value in the display area by this constant, to convert from kilometers per hour to miles per hour. For example, 8 * Con C0 = 5.
Divide the current value in the display area by this constant, to convert from miles per hour to kilometers per hour. For example, 5 / Con C0 = 8.
Multiply the current value in the display area by this constant, to convert from inches to centimeters. For example, 12 * Con C4 = 30.
Divide the current value in the display area by this constant, to convert from centimeters to inches. For example, 30 / Con C4 = 12.
Multiply the current value in the display area by this constant, to convert from grams to ounces. For example, 500 * Con C7 = 18.
Divide the current value in the display area by this constant, to convert from ounces to grams. For example, 18 / Con C7 = 500.
Multiply the current value in the display area by this constant, to convert from kilojoules to British thermal units. For example, 10 * Con C8 = 9.48.
Divide the current value in the display area by this constant, to convert from British thermal units to kilojoules. For example, 9.48 / Con C8 = 10.
Multiply the current value in the display area by this constant, to convert from cubic centimeters to cubic inches. For example, 100 * Con C9 = 6.10.
Divide the current value in the display area by this constant, to convert from cubic inches to cubic centimeters. For example, 6.10 / Con C9 = 100.

sect3.para: In this version of &app;, it is not possible to add new constants. However, you can store your own constants by overwriting the default constants.
To store a new constant or edit an existing constant, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Click on Con and select Edit Constants... from the popup menu. The Edit Constants window appears:
Select the constant that you want to overwrite or edit.
Click on the Value field, and enter the new value.
Click on the Description field, and enter the new description.
Click OK to save your changes and close the Edit Constants window.

sect3.title: To Use Functions
sect3.para: To show the available functions, click on Fun. The keyboard equivalent is F. A popup menu displays the list of defined functions; select a function from the menu to run that function. If using the keyboard equivalent F, you can use the keyboard to specify the appropriate function. For example, F 3 enters in the display area the value returned by executing function F3; if F3 is not defined, the value zero is returned.
&app; does not provide any default functions. You can store up to ten functions.
To store a new function or edit an existing function, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Click on Fun and select Edit Functions... from the popup menu. The Edit Functions window appears:
Select a blank entry, or the function that you want to overwrite.
Click on the Value field, and enter the new value. Use the keyboard equivalents to invoke a &app; button; for example, 90K to calculate sine(90).
Click on the Description field, and enter the new description. For example, Sine 90.
Click OK to save your changes and close the Edit Functions window.

sect3.title: To Manipulate Binary Numbers
sect3.para: To manipulate binary numbers, use the buttons described in .

entry.para: Shifts the current (unsigned 32-bit) binary value in the display area, the specified number of places to the left. Click on <, and select the appropriate number of shift places from the popup menu. The number can be shifted up to 15 places left.

If using the keyboard equivalent <, you can use the keyboard to specify the appropriate places to shift to the left. For example, < 4 will shift the current binary value in the display area 4 places to the left.

Shifts the current (unsigned 32-bit) binary value in the display area, the specified number of places to the right. Click on >, and select the appropriate number of shift places from the popup menu. The number can be shifted up to 15 places right.

If using the keyboard equivalent >, you can use the keyboard to specify the appropriate places to shift to the right. For example, > 4 will shift the current binary value in the display area 4 places to the right.
Truncates the current value in the display area and returns a 16-bit unsigned integer.
Truncates the current value in the display area and returns a 32-bit unsigned integer.

sect3.title: To Perform Miscellaneous Scientific Calculations
sect3.para: To calculate miscellaneous scientific calculations, use the buttons described in .

entry.para: Provide precedence in arithmetic calculations; calculations within parentheses are performed first. If parentheses are not used, arithmetic calculations are performed from left to right with no arithmetic precedence. Parentheses can be nested to any level. When the last parenthesis is matched, the display area is updated.
Calculates the value of e raised to the power of the current value in the display area.
Calculates the value of 10 raised to the power of the current value in the display area.
Raises the current value in the display area to the power of the next value entered.
Calculates the factorial (that is, x*(x-1)*(x-2)...*1) of the current value in the display area. This function applies only to positive integers.
Generates a random number in the range 0.0 to 1.0 and displays the random number in the display area.
These numerals are active in hexadecimal base only.

sect2.title: Order of Operations
sect2.para: Calculations are performed from left to right with no arithmetic precedence. To apply arithmetic precedence, use parentheses.
For example, without parentheses: 2 + 3 * 4 = 20 With parentheses: 2 + (3 * 4) = 14

sect2.title: Error Conditions
sect2.para: If you perform an invalid calculation, the calculator displays the word Error in the display area to indicate an error. For example, if you try to calculate the log of a negative number, the calculator displays the word Error. To clear the error, click on Clr or press Delete.

sect2.title: To Change the Input Mode
sect2.para: To change the input mode, right-click in the text window, then select Input Methods.
